messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Tsuba kantie
messages.msgSnippet: Ron et al- I agree the cut-out shapes could be sotoba but I am looking at the positive outline and see four bats around the rim. Whatever it is this is the
messages.messageBody:
Ron et al-
I agree the cut-out shapes could be sotoba but I am looking at the
positive outline and see four bats around the rim. Whatever it is
this is the most interesting piece I've seen posted in a while, I
love anything that can't be catagorized other than "solid". This
looks to be a solid piece o tsuba...
-t
Tom Helm
toryu@...
"Moriamur, et in media arma ruamas"
- Virgil



>

messages.subject: Re: Tsuba kantie
messages.msgSnippet: Dear Ron To comment briefly on your fascinating and enigmatic tsuba, the openings at the four corners of the guard are reminiscent, to me, of the entrants that
messages.messageBody:
Dear Ron

To comment briefly on your fascinating and enigmatic tsuba, the
openings at the four corners of the guard are reminiscent, to me, of
the entrants that are more commonly tri-lobed, and appear singly on
old, aoie-shaped tsuba. Not that this is of any help at all of
course, since I believe that nobody has yet proposed a possible
significance for these!

Regards, John L.


--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Ron Hartmann" <swords@...>
wrote:
>
> Thanks John. The 3-leaf sukashi (if that what it is) does resemble
kiri leaves but I wanted to hear that from somebody else. The strange
patina is just the quality of the photo...probably a scan. Oddly,
that off-color shows up the black lacquer, at least I think that's
what I'm seeing on the posted view. I find this rather fascinating
little tsuba, my reason for seeking some feedback from fresh eyes.
>
> I'm going to send a couple "tests" out after this email. Strange,
my nihontostudy email and yahoo email both came back here and was
dumped into my spam folder. No replies needed for the "test."
>
> Ron

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Tsuba kantie
messages.msgSnippet: Ron, Top and bottom of the tsuba are the sukashi mon of the Mickey Mouse clan of Higo. Only slightly more seriously, the kozuka / kogai ana have the buddhist
messages.messageBody:
Ron,

Top and bottom of the tsuba are the sukashi mon of the
Mickey Mouse clan of Higo.

Only slightly more seriously, the kozuka / kogai ana
have the buddhist pole (or baby bottle shape) that I
usually associate with Higo designs. After that, you
need to make the call whether the metal matches to any
other Higo tsuba you've seen.

Odd tsuba. Nice to see it.

Curran


--- Ron Hartmann <swords@...> wrote:

> Hi -
>
> I'm seeking some comments on an interesting old
> tsuba in my collection. It is iron sukashi work of a
> very unusual (undescribable, to me) shape and
> design. It measures 70mm x 58mm x 6mm and has
> remnants of black lacquer remaining on it. The
> hitsu-ana pillows are interesting in that hey are
> double-layered, the inside inlay being shakudo with
> a silver overlaid plate. The tsuba has not been cut
> down so this is its original shape, in my opinion.
> Obviously it has been refitted many times. A photo
> is posted in nihontostudy pictures under Ron STL.
> (posted under two groups...so one should work for
> you.)
>
> http://tinyurl.com/2vyzfc
>
> http://tinyurl.com/2z2u8j
>
> Any and all comments welcomed.
>
> Ron
> STL
>
> [Non-text portions of this message have been
> removed]
>
>

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Tsuba kantie
messages.msgSnippet: John - Looking at kiri in Chappelear s mon book I looked further and discovered that the ivy better represents what this design is on my tsuba. The kiri
messages.messageBody:
John -

Looking at "kiri" in Chappelear's mon book I looked further and discovered that the "ivy" better represents what this design is on my tsuba. The "kiri" of course has the three "blooms" and the "ivy" does not. Check out p.37, particularly the left column, third up. I think that's it. As for the other sukashi designs between the "ivy," could be anybody's guess.

I've added another photo to my file, one with a black background if anyone's interested in looking. Its a little more realistic (patina).

Ron
STL

----- Original Message -----
From: Ron Hartmann
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Wednesday, March 19, 2008 7:50 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Tsuba kantie


Thanks John. The 3-leaf sukashi (if that what it is) does resemble kiri leaves but I wanted to hear that from somebody else. The strange patina is just the quality of the photo...probably a scan. Oddly, that off-color shows up the black lacquer, at least I think that's what I'm seeing on the posted view. I find this rather fascinating little tsuba, my reason for seeking some feedback from fresh eyes.

I'm going to send a couple "tests" out after this email. Strange, my nihontostudy email and yahoo email both came back here and was dumped into my spam folder. No replies needed for the "test."

Ron
STL
----- Original Message -----
From: excelsiorilluminati
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Wednesday, March 19, 2008 4:22 PM
Subject: [nihontostudy] Re: Tsuba kantie


Hi Ron, A rather strange patina. Looks brassy coloured in areas.
Lighting probably, eh? The sukashi look to be kirimon in shape. Don't
know about the ovals. Nice for a change, from marugata. John

--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Ron Hartmann" <swords@...>

remnants of black lacquer remaining on it. The hitsu-ana pillows are
interesting in that hey are double-layered, the inside inlay being
shakudo with a silver overlaid plate. The tsuba has not been cut

messages.messageBody:
Thanks John. The 3-leaf sukashi (if that what it is) does resemble kiri leaves but I wanted to hear that from somebody else. The strange patina is just the quality of the photo...probably a scan. Oddly, that off-color shows up the black lacquer, at least I think that's what I'm seeing on the posted view. I find this rather fascinating little tsuba, my reason for seeking some feedback from fresh eyes.

I'm going to send a couple "tests" out after this email. Strange, my nihontostudy email and yahoo email both came back here and was dumped into my spam folder. No replies needed for the "test."

Ron
STL

messages.subject: Tsuba kantie
messages.msgSnippet: Hi - I m seeking some comments on an interesting old tsuba in my collection. It is iron sukashi work of a very unusual (undescribable, to me) shape and design.
messages.messageBody:
Hi -

I'm seeking some comments on an interesting old tsuba in my collection. It is iron sukashi work of a very unusual (undescribable, to me) shape and design. It measures 70mm x 58mm x 6mm and has remnants of black lacquer remaining on it. The hitsu-ana pillows are interesting in that hey are double-layered, the inside inlay being shakudo with a silver overlaid plate. The tsuba has not been cut down so this is its original shape, in my opinion. Obviously it has been refitted many times. A photo is posted in nihontostudy pictures under Ron STL. (posted under two groups...so one should work for you.)

http://tinyurl.com/2vyzfc

http://tinyurl.com/2z2u8j

Any and all comments welcomed.

Ron
STL

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
